channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Afghanistan: British nationals killed in Kabul airport attack
item.description: Two British nationals and the child of another are among the victims of Thursday's attack, the government says.

item.title: Afghanistan: Every effort was made to destroy Kabul staff details, says Foreign Office
item.description: The UK says "every effort" was made to destroy sensitive papers when the embassy was evacuated.

item.title: Government to ban single-use plastic cutlery
item.description: Plastic plates and polystyrene cups will also be banned in England in what ministers call a "war on plastic".

item.title: Afghanistan: Starmer calls for help for those left behind
item.description: Sir Keir Starmer says those left behind in the evacuation need an urgent plan to protect them.

item.title: COP26: Queen to attend climate conference in Glasgow
item.description: The monarch will join leaders including Pope Francis and US President Joe Biden at the UN event in November.

item.title: No lasting homelessness fix after Covid scheme
item.description: A charity says fewer than one in four people helped by the Everyone In initiative now have permanent homes.

item.title: Brexit: Irish support for deal harming NI, says DUP leader
item.description: Sir Jeffrey Donaldson's claim comes after a meeting with Taoiseach Micheál Martin in Dublin.

item.title: Covid travel: Seven locations moved to Covid travel green list
item.description: Canada and Denmark go on the green list while Thailand and Montenegro move to the UK red list.

item.title: Morrisons calls for action on lorry driver dearth
item.description: The supermarket chain joins others in the food and drink industry demanding a special help with visas.

item.title: French presidency: Michel Barnier joins race 'to change France'
item.description: The former EU Brexit negotiator says he will take on Emmanuel Macron in the elections next spring.

item.title: Make universal credit top-up permanent - Tory MPs
item.description: The call comes as charities warn that cutting the £20 top-up will push millions of families into debt.

item.title: Tory accounts show donor paid towards PM flat refurb bill
item.description: Conservative party accounts reveal Lord Brownlow initially covered refurb costs totalling nearly £53,000.

item.title: Data protection 'shake-up' takes aim at cookie pop-ups
item.description: A new head has been appointed to the UK data regulator amid a plan to drive the economy using data.

item.title: Scottish Greens co-leaders Harvie and Slater to be given minister roles
item.description: The Scottish Green Party confirms that Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater will become ministers if a new power-sharing deal is approved.

item.title: NHS blood test tube shortage set to worsen
item.description: NHS England admits supplies of the tubes will become "even more constrained over the coming weeks".

item.title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak has new pool, gym and tennis court approved
item.description: Rishi Sunak is granted planning permission to make changes to his listed manor house in Yorkshire.

item.title: NI minister apologises for hospital waiting lists
item.description: More than half of patients waiting for a first consultant appointment in NI wait more than a year.

item.title: Unite union elects Sharon Graham as first woman leader
item.description: Sharon Graham replaces Len McCluskey, and vows to focus on workers' rights rather than Westminster politics.

item.title: Boris Johnson: Tories feared PM would die with Covid, says Simon Hart
item.description: The Welsh secretary says there were concerns Boris Johnson would die when he was ill with Covid-19.

item.title: Tesco and Iceland bosses warn over Christmas supplies
item.description: But Tesco's chairman says don't "overdramatise" lorry driver crisis, as Iceland warns problem getting worse.

item.title: Dominic Raab: With hindsight I wouldn't have gone on holiday
item.description: But the foreign secretary says the idea he was "lounging on the beach" as the Taliban advanced was "nonsense".

item.title: Extinction Rebellion: Nearly 200 arrests over four days
item.description: Campaigners have glued themselves to a giant table and formed a human chain around Oxford Circus.

item.title: Afghanistan: Talks held on Welsh support for refugees
item.description: The first minister, council leaders and charities meet as evacuations from Kabul pick up pace.

item.title: Starmer: Urgent plan needed for those left in Afghanistan
item.description: The Labour leaders says "searing questions" await the government over its handling of the Afghan crisis.

item.title: Afghanistan: Wallace says UK will evacuate final 1,000 people on Friday
item.description: Defence Secretary Ben Wallace says the UK has entered the last stages of its evacuation operations at Kabul airport.

item.title: PM: 'Vulnerabilities to terrorism' at this stage of evacuation
item.description: Boris Johnson says the evacuation operation will continue despite deadly explosions at Kabul airport.

item.title: Raab: With hindsight I wouldn't have gone on holiday
item.description: The foreign secretary says he was focused on Afghanistan, despite being abroad when Kabul fell.

item.title: Afghanistan evacuation: 'We'll use every remaining hour and day' - Raab
item.description: UK Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab gives an update on the evacuations from Afghanistan.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the £20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the £20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey wants to target Tory heartlands
item.description: Smashing Tory dominance in the party's traditional areas is Liberal Democrats leader Ed Davey's plan. Can it work?

item.title: Levelling up: The seaside town debating what change is needed
item.description: As a report says levelling up plans must consider local views, people in Rhyl debate the changes needed.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who originally supported Trump's deal with the Taliban?
item.description: UK Defence Secretary Ben Wallace now calls it a "rotten" deal but supported it at the time.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: Woke: Compliment or criticism, it is now fuelling the culture wars
item.description: The surprising history of a term increasingly thrown around in UK political debate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Who is Dominic Raab?
item.description: A profile of the foreign secretary, as he comes under fire for his handling of the Afghanistan crisis.

item.title: Boris Johnson feels MPs' anger during Afghanistan debate
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.
